findings.title: ELFM - Exceeds Fees Limit
findings.description: The contract imposes transaction fees exceeding the allowed limit of 25%. Specifically, it charges a 30% fee for the first 100 transactions.

findings.title: ITH - Inefficient Transaction Handling
findings.description: The contract's `_transfer` function inefficiently handles transaction fees and count transactions, resulting in unnecessary overhead and gas consumption.

findings.title: RFU - Redundant Flag Usage
findings.description: The contract contains a redundant `Flag` enum and `flag` variable within the `_transfer` function, which are not utilized in any subsequent code segments or logic.

findings.title: RCS - Redundant Code Segments
findings.description: The contract contains redundant code segments, including the `_maxTokens` variable and the `setMinTokens` and `_addLiquidity` functions, which are not used in the contract's logic or functionality.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that their value is initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide is a set of guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code. Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.
